comments.text:
I will answer the first question. The others I feel would be a little over 
my head since I know only the basics of evolution and the questions you ask 
are impossible to answer at this point in time. But that does not mean that 
there is no explanation that is not god.
With the breathing newborns, it's instinct. Most babies cry when they first 
leave the womb, and that is when they take their first breathe. Some babies 
don't cry when they are first born and the doctors have to make them 
because them crying makes them learn to use their lungs. Before that they 
received their oxygen through the umbilical chord, so it's not like they 
are experiencing oxygen for the first time. 
The body has a natural reaction to loss of oxygen in the lungs, and it is 
to gasp. Babies don't inherently know to breathe, but their body figures it 
out for them.

to all atheists:

If I told you that a deer was in my backyard, and you see deer tracks, deer 
feces, and find deer fur, you will imfer that there was a deer present. 
Now, think of a god. There are many apparent tracks he has left, and 
sometimes we have to believe in the unseen. 

For example, I am muslim, and in the Quran (which has been proven to not 
have changed) it explains the orbital of the planets (which could not have 
been known 1400 years ago), it explains the creation of life, originating 
from the sperm (which could also not be known). It says things about 
pharoah, before he was born. This obviously could not be known. These are 
just three of countless miracles.

Also the quran is text that can not be compared to. There have been 
countless scholars who try to come up with text as complex and beautiful as 
the Quran, but they never come close. Within a specific three short verses 
of the Quran, there were over 40 literary elements used. 

Finally, to refute the atheistic view. OK, i get it. The big bang. But, who 
caused it?? One year from now, the sun will come up at exactly the same 
time as today. Nothing major has ever collided with earth to severely harm 
the human race. We havent been hit by major solar storms. And im expected 
to believe that BANG, and the sun is there, coming up the exact same time 
every year, and BANG the human race is forever protected from solar 
dangers. This doesnt make much sense to me. Another thing is evolution. 
There is a major flaw in the theory of evolution. Where did single cellular 
organisms originate? this is still not known to this date. Somehow, the sun 
just magically cultivated life. Life comes from life, and this has been 
proven by scientists, so how could life come from nothing.

For me, there is obviously someone who created life. And, in my belief, it 
is Allah.﻿

comments.text:
I have no problem with you choosing to believe whatever you end up 
believing.... but please, for your own sanity, don't EVER say 'you can't 
prove he is not real.' That's a pandora's box. because by saying that very 
thing, you basically say everything exists until proven not to - so.. 
unicorns, faeries, santa, tooth fairy, slenderman, cosmic teapot, 
extrasolar lightspeed rhino... you can't prove none of these are real.

'who made all this happen' is an impossible question, because if there is 
no answer involving a 'who' then the question will still be asked. it's a 
malformed question, because the way you ask it presupposes that there was a 
sentient being behind it. Science hasn't does not stop there being a 
sentient being behind the universe, but at this current point in time, 
there is no evidence there is. if evidence were to come about that there 
is, you can be sure that scientists will eventually chase down an answer as 
to 'who'.

Ooh, do I detect a hint of pascal's wager? well, I would believe in one 
less god than you. And i'm pretty sure that in most religions, the penalty 
for not believing, is much less than the penalty for believing in the wrong 
god. So I ask you.. What if Allah is real, and you've been following the 
wrong practices - If YOU are right, both the jews, and the muslims, have 
been believing in the right god, but following the wrong practices - and 
are doomed to hell. What if The egyptians were right in their beliefs? I 
could go on all day, asking the same question about numerous religions. I'd 
rather be doomed to a lesser hell for not holding a belief, than a worse 
hell for making the wrong choice.

I believe those who need to believe in a god are in pain, and often lonely. 
I don't understand the desire to seek such a belief, when the world we live 
in and the people we meet, provide us with more happiness and joy than you 
could wish for. I don't make fun of those who believe in any god, I take 
that seriously. But.. when it comes to the gods themselves... there is 
often much to mock. There's zeus turning into a swan, The schizophrenic 
nature of the abrahamic god, the power hungry narcissistic nature of the 
abrahamic god.. the even more narcissistic nature of the egyptian gods.. 
All these gods have some easily mockable features.

Oh, and the reason i'm speaking to you as I am, is because of how you 
speak. You condescend, and label athiests as 'ignorant.' Many outspoken 
athiests know more of the bible than many christians. We've thought through 
the beliefs. we've considered pascals wager. we have gone through 'soul 
searching'. And we have found ourself unable to accept the religious 
beliefs we've been shown, in light of everything else in the world around 
us.
comments.author: Nathan Glazier

+lobotomystitches Atheists religiously believe that there is no God.
Theists religiously believe that there is a God.
An Agnostic is somebody who doesn't know, because they can't prove either, 
even if they don't care either way.

 If people say 'they don't believe anything', they are saying that they 
don't believe in any of the religions but that *doesn't* mean they are 
saying that they think 'God doesn't exist'. So these people are *Agnostic*. 
Most Agnostics say 'they don't know'.

Alternatively, if there are people who say that 'They don't believe 
anything' and then they foolishly go on to say that they think 'God isn't 
real' (it is foolish because it contradicts what they said previously, not 
that I think that if you say' God is not real' that you are foolish) then 
they are are fundamentally *Atheists* and that means that they do 'believe' 
in something. Their previous statement is invalid and incorrect because 
after they say 'God isn't real' they are stating a belief, and beliefs are 
beliefs because fundamentally they are *unproven*.

So in summary: Atheism and Theism *are* beliefs. Agnosticism and that 
*alone* is a lack of a belief. Simple and easy logic.

comments.text:
+Vanessa Ortiz You're not getting my point. It's honestly a waste of time 
trying to convince someone of something they don't believe in, you're 
obviously a Christian. If a muslim came to you and tried to convince you to 
switch faith he'd be wasting his time as would you be if you tried to 
convince him to switch his. I grew up in a very, very religious family but 
when I got to 14 I started to question it. There were so many questions no 
one could answer, so many things that made no sense and if you read a bible 
from the 1600's it's almost a completely different text from the one we 
have now because things keep getting added and taken away from it all the 
time to make it relevant to modern society.
comments.author: FlynnRider

comments.text:
Im just educating ppl of my knowledge of God and think its so sad that 
someone would be so closeminded about something so amazing..Wish more ppl 
wouldnt be so blind.. And who who are you to say that I cant prove a 
point..And trust me im not sitting around crying for your disbelief.. your 
the one missing out..I just wish I had more ppl to rejoice in the Lord with 
me..
comments.author: Vanessa Ortiz

comments.text:
+Vanessa Ortiz But who are we to inform people of things they don't 
believe? I've read the bible, I've studied it but I still don't believe 
most of it. Don't get me wrong, I genuinely believe Jesus was real but I 
don't for a second believe he was the son of god. yes he was a man who did 
great things and spread a fantastic message to the world but that doesn't 
make him the son of god, He was just the Gandhi of his time in my opinion. 
Trying to inform people of something they don't beleive is as redundant as 
trying to tell a meat eater why he should become vegan. I think we're all 
entitled to our opinions but in some circumstances we need to keep those 
opinions to ourselves. it's fine to share them but don't sit whining about 
it when someone doesn't agree with you. In this day and age religion is as 
taboo a subject as incest or cannibalism. I have friends who believe and 
others that don't and it's a subject we all avoid talking about because it 
will end in an argument.
comments.author: FlynnRider

comments.text:
+BackToBaskin Atheists also believe god MAY exist, but don't currently 
believe in the existence. This is agnostic atheism.

Agnostics don't claim knowledge. Agnosticism says NOTHING about BELIEF, it 
only pertains to knowledge.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agnostic_atheism

You're using words you don't know the definition for.

Agnostic is NOT a "middle position" as most people think it is. There are 2 
questions, and 2 answers for each, making 4 possible positions
1) do you BELIEVE in a god? (theistic)
2) do you KNOW there is a god? (gnostic)

a) agnostic atheist - disbelieves but does not claim certainty
b) gnostic atheist - disbelieves and claims certainty in the non-existence 
of a god
c) agnostic theist - believes in the existence of a god but does not assert 
certainty
d) gnostic theist - claims believe in a god and certainty

You're wrong and you need to accept this

This is an easy to read resource

http://wiki.ironchariots.org/index.php?title=Atheist_vs._agnostic
comments.author: ThePharphis

comments.author: ThePharphis

comments.text:
+ThePharphis
If you're uncertain, you don't take a side. It means the same thing in 
terms of atheism vs belief. You're neither atheist or Christian. You can't 
exactly say you're an agnostic who doesn't know what is or isn't true and 
at the same time you're an atheist who believes it isn't true. That 
literally wouldn't make sense. For someone to say they're an agnostic 
atheist would be going "Yeah, I admit I have no certainties about the 
existence of this being but it also doesn't exist to me."  It's impossible 
to be both. It's like saying you're a violent pacifist.
comments.author: BackToBaskin

comments.text:
+BackToBaskin It's just a catchy 3-liner. And like a commenter above 
pointed out: you can be a "pragmatic agnostic" which yes, means you on some 
level can mean  you don't care about the fight. Although I think you're 
right that it's probably better to call that an apatheist to avoid 
misinformation.

And yea... as ThePharphis pointed out, the main thing about agnosticism is 
not that it's about not taking a side: it's that it's about not claiming 
certainty - this is taking a side. i.e. the third side that we either cant 
be certain or aren't currently certain. In the schoolyard fight, I think 
it's better to see it as the agnostic being the one that would tell the 
theist and the atheist that they might both be wrong and that both of them 
actually don't or cant have certainty in their views... and that they 
should convert to the agnostic side and both stop believing with such 
certainty in their views.

The apatheist is the guy (in shades) under the tree eating lunch and not 
giving a shit about the fight between the agnostic, atheist and theist in 
front of him.
comments.author: Dirk Haupt

comments.text:
+BackToBaskin agnostic doesn't mean you don't take a side, either.

Agnostic means you don't claim certainty. You can still BELIEVE (agnostic 
theist) or DISBELIEVE (agnostic atheist)

Wow! The "God" comments are getting hundreds of replies! Once again it's 
Atheists vs. Christians, while most of us who believe God is a collective, 
quietly watch in amusement...because we understand ignorance. It's a dirty 
job, but someones gotta do it so knowledge can come to light.
Christians, Jesus was clear that he was the son of God, but when did He 
ever even imply that we were less than Him? Only a few hints at what must 
have really pissed off the Pharisees, still remain in the Bible.
"Ye must be perfect, even as your heavenly Father is perfect" Matthew 5:48
"Verily, verily, I say unto you, He that believeth on me, the works that I 
do shall he do also; and greater works than these shall he do" John 14:12
"Jesus answered them, Is it not written in your law, I said, Ye are gods?" 
John 10:34
"Neither shall they say, Lo here! or, lo there! for, behold, the kingdom of 
God is within you." Luke 17:21
"When you come to know yourselves, then you will become known, and you will 
realize that it is you who are the sons of the living father." Gospel of 
Thomas.
How many more such teachings are locked up in the Vatican? Seems no 
religious or political hierarchy would fare well if everyone else was being 
taught their Divinity by someone like Yeshua. Why would the Pharisees be so 
afraid of one man claiming he was the son of God? If He was actually 
claiming we ALL are Sons of God, now that would be something to eliminate 
and cover up.﻿
top_comment.author: kelhawk1

comments.text:
+Zach Williams Thanks for disagreeing so respectfully Zach, apparently "the 
Kingdom of Heaven is within you" and "nothing shall be impossible unto you" 
means something different to you than it does me. That's absolutely cool, 
because I also think the "eye for an eye, tooth for a tooth" thing should 
be interpreted: "If I take your eye, I should give you mine", rather than: 
"If you take my eye I am entitled to yours". Isn't it strange that the 
popular interpretation of this Bible verse is about revenge and vengeance, 
more like what "Satan" would tempt us to do, rather than compassion and 
forgiveness, that which God would encourage us to do? It kinda makes me 
question other popular interpretations. Silly me.
Thanks for the Matthew 11:11 quote, it makes perfect sense in my view also, 
and I will include it in my book...which is basically about not putting all 
your eggs in one basket...especially a really old and altered basket. A 
proper understanding of that verse would depend on what the words "least" 
and "greater" originally referred to. Greater and less what? muscle, 
brains, love, spiritual evolution? Maybe favor with God? If 
God/Unconditional Love chooses favorites, how's that unconditional, or any 
form of higher love? Maybe it's simply least and greater vibration...and 
perhaps it's best to "Judge not, lest ye be judged", because we have all 
chosen to forget we temporarily lowered our vibration to be better able to 
"play in the fields of the Lord." The fields of the Lord is the experience 
of Good and Evil, where "for everything there is a season..."
Here's some intriguing words: "Even as ye do unto these, the least of my 
Brethren, so ye also do unto me." If Yeshua considered us less than 
Himself, why did He give us the word "Brethren", but NEVER anything like 
the word "Subjects"?  If the Kingdom is within, why do we need an outside 
influence interceding for our salvation? Giving credit for your power to 
move mountains to He who is actually One with You, your "brethren", is less 
than who you truly are.
Btw none of this is directed to you personally, it's for the curious who 
are looking for something more.
comments.author: kelhawk1

comments.text:
I'd have to disagree with the "God is a collective" idea.  Approaching God 
on a strictly intellectual level I could see the initial logic in that 
assertion.  However, most  of Jesus' speech in the gospels appears centered 
around needing to become better than what we are now (repenting). He also 
speaks several times on the ascension of those who are worthy to follow 
him, after his own.  Pretty strong indicator to me God is on a whole level 
of existence above our own, and we must better ourselves before we might 
rise up, so to speak (i.e. He was/is His own individual self from the 
beginning.
  As for hints/quotes, I think this one's relevant. --

"Truly I say to you, among those born of women there has arisen no one 
greater than John The Baptist; yet he who is least in the kingdom of heaven 
is greater than he."  (Matthew, 11-11)

comments.author: Augustine Kyei

comments.text:
+Augustine Kyei Actually, Jesus didn't. He said they'll go into hell fire, 
which is death by fire, it doesn't mean they will live on in conscious 
torment forever. Forever and eternal were always used to translate a word 
in Greek (Aionos) that meant an age, or "unquenchable", or forever. They 
always translated it into forever and eternal because that's what they 
believed about "hell", which also was used to translate three words; "sheol 
(the grave), Gehenna (a trash dump outside of Israel), and Tartarus (where 
the Bible says the fallen angels are chained). Considering that in multiple 
places, the Bible says that when you die, your thoughts die, you go back to 
the dust, etc, etc.; the Bible would contradict itself all over the place 
if you interpret those "forevers" and "eternals" to mean sinners suffer 
eternal torment.

This understanding of what's involved in hellfire and hell in general 
really needs to be straightened out.
comments.author: Lynette Summers

comments.text:
Because murders, moral judgements, and infringement upon the rights of 
others are not committed in the name of Batman--and if one person were to 
do this, it would be assumed that they are acting and thinking 
irrationally, and thus not taken seriously.  Yet in much of the world, we 
have chosen to give legitimacy to equally absurd claims so pervasively 
(through acceptance) that our entire species can be stagnant and often 
regressive.  People should absolutely be allowed to believe as they please, 
but when others are psychologically effected to a severe detriment, it 
becomes abusive.  

I enjoy DC, but more specifically, the Vertigo imprint has always been my 
personal favorite.  There is no operational definition on what makes a 
better comic (subjectivity), so the argument is moot.

comments.text:
+MasterChief0522 That comment wasn't remotely smart (I can only imagine the 
smug look on your face as you posted it, though!), especially with the 
second sentence basically tearing it apart with the baseless assumption 
that the Big Bang Theory is true. It's a theory. Get a dictionary and look 
that word up. Then, go over what makes a scientific theory popular; 
countless positives strengthening it with zero negatives rendering the 
theory untrue. This is what advances the hypothesis into a well-accepted 
theory. Our theory regarding gravity is one of these.

See it this way:
I make a new theory that everything, when dropped, falls straight down. I 
drop several items and, well damn, they fall. Then I drop a piece of paper 
and it goes flying away in the breeze. Is paper the exception to my rule? 
Did something lift the paper up? Either way, my theory is broken. Dropping 
straight down is no longer an unconditional matter. There are variables 
which are throwing it off that I must now figure out through rigorous 
testing.

Religion is a similar principle, but instead of working off of positives 
with zero negatives it's a gut feeling combined with zero negatives. I'm 
sure any rational religious folk would acknowledge that they're incorrect 
when a negative is provided. But none have been, so until then saying they 
are 100% right or wrong is impossible. You can disagree, but at that point 
it's a matter of opinion. Scientific theories that aren't proven themselves 
cannot be used as evidence, let alone proof, that these religious beliefs 
are false.

So hey, that invisible pink dragon may just as well be there. ;P

than ONE BOOK to understand how our universe works... from the beginning of 
the universe, to the beginning of life, to the emergence of

top_comment.text:
It's actually believed that Atlantis is the Minoan island or inspired the 
story of it, as there are MANY similarities between the two.﻿
top_comment.author: Ionlymadethistoleavecoments

comments.text:
I understand what you mean, but some very large similarities are:

The island as described by the author (I believe homer) was 2-3 circles one 
inside the other with bridges connecting them. The Minoan island present 
day has two crescent shaped islands, and archeologists believe it very well 
could have been circles at one point

The atlantians were supposed to be highly advanced. Although not as 
advanced as the description of Atlantis, the Minoans were very advanced for 
their neighbors, even having a form of plumbing.

The atlantians were said to worship bulls. The Minoans too had a religious 
devotion to the bull, even offering sacrifices

The atlantians were written to have largely died after a cataclysmic 
volcanoes eruption. The Minoans too were wiped out by a massive eruption

Finally, the writer (again, I believe homer) was either Greek or lived near 
the region. The Minoan island is around the area of Greece and the 
Mediterranean.
comments.author: Ionlymadethistoleavecoments

comments.text:
I agree, the bible is real.  It was assembled by the Nicean Council quite a 
long time ago to help cement what they felt were Christian ideals (with a 
healthy dose of political influence to help consolidate power).  They had 
some funny rules about which books could go into the canon, like 'no female 
authors'.  It isn't hard to assemble a canon of books where its message 
remains the same if you get to choose the books you assemble into the 
canon.  If you have the liberty of leaving out things like the books 
assembled into the Apocrypha (which contain things like The Gospel 
According To Mary, yet another creation story that seems to favor Lucifer, 
and other interesting ideas), you can make a message consistent.

Taken with this information in mind, the bible really is an instruction 
booklet.  It is a booklet of instructions less from some caring deity of 
some kind, and more from a group of now long-dead men who wanted to 
maintain control over other men, by convincing them that they would be 
'happy' despite the remarkably awful living conditions for the majority of 
Europeans during Rome's decline, and the terrible feudalism that swept 
through the lands (not unlike what we're starting to experience in the 
United States, as the rich consolidate more wealth to themselves and leave 
everyone else following this same instruction booklet, or maybe the Quoran).

Funny thing is, people generally seemed happier once scientific ideals were 
embraced rather than fought.  Our standard of living improved, and we 
started making useful tools once we stopped religiously following books 
like the bible and started making cogent conclusions of our observations.

Yes, life is rather complicated.  Scientific observations have shown just 
how complicated it is.  It's way more complicated than religious texts 
would have you believe.  And its existence isn't necessarily proof of god's 
existence or non-existence.

You can ascribe things that science hasn't explained yet to religion if it 
makes you comfortable, but you steal curiosity from yourself with such 
explanations, which may prevent you from wondering why certain observations 
are as they are.  After all, why bother trying to figure out if evolution 
is guided or not if you have convinced yourself that some unseen 
intelligence is pulling the strings?  Why bother trying to ascertain if 
that unseen intelligence is a god or your own ancestors if you have 
convinced yourself that it's a god pulling the strings?  Ironically, by not 
trying to understand your observations, you risk not understanding god (if 
god exists), or the reality in which you live (if god doesn't exist).

(BTW: Not that I expect it, but don't trust everything I've written here as 
correct.  Research it yourself.  See if I'm full of crap, or have certain 
details wrong.  Do your own research).
comments.author: fleeb

powerful idea that as the sun rises in the sky and the air heats up and as,

the notion that everything's going to be alright, because this world was 
meant to have him in it, was built to have him in it; so the moment he

comments.text:
+LORDUnLuCkY13  Right time to shut you all up, Enjoy the read.

The biggest problem for evolutionists is the origin of life from non-life. 
Even the simplest single-celled organism is unthinkably complex, with 
scores of highly-sophisticated parts, all performing important functions 
and all mutually interdependent. The laws of statistics have convinced all 
who have bothered to calculate that even a protein molecule, consisting as 
it does of a chain of hundreds of precisely arranged amino acids, could 
never arise by chance. And such a protein molecule is trivial compared to 
any of the working parts of a cell. When it is recognized that all of these 
parts must be present and functioning at the start, it must be admitted 
that life from non-life is impossible without intelligent design. Actually, 
any living thing gives such strong evidence for design by an intelligent 
designer that only a willful ignoring of the data (II Peter 3:5) could lead 
one to assign such intricacy to chance. Every living thing, from simple 
bacteria to people, possesses the marvelous DNA code, which contains a 
library full of precise information, and without which life is impossible.
Another huge problem for evolutionists lies in the nature of the fossil 
record, i.e., the only physical record we have of life in the past. As is 
now being admitted by my evolutionary colleagues, the fossil record gives 
no clue that any basic type of animal has ever changed into another basic 
type of animal, for no in-between forms have ever been discovered. Each 
basic type is distinct in the modern world and in the fossil record, 
although there is much variation within these basic types. While gradual, 
"Darwinian" evolution has always predicted that in-between forms would one 
day be found, the current rage in evolutionary circles is the concept of 
rapid evolution, or "punctuated equilibrium"—proposing that small isolated 
portions of a larger population evolved rapidly and left no fossils. But 
where is the evidence that they evolved at all?
Even though the gaps in the fossil record are found between each basic 
animal type, there are two huge gaps, which should be emphasized. The 
evolutionary distance between single celled organisms and the vast array of 
multicellular, highly complex marine invertebrates precludes even rapid 
evolution. In the supposedly 600-million-year-old layers of rock designated 
as Cambrian (the first appearance of multicelled life), sponges, clams, 
trilobites, sea urchins, starfish, etc., etc., are found with no 
evolutionary ancestors. Evolutionists don't even have any possible 
ancestors to propose. And then the gap from marine invertebrates to the 
vertebrate fish is likewise immense. To make matters worse for the 
evolutionists, fish fossils are also found in Cambrian strata. If evolution 
is true, fish must have evolved from something, and invertebrates must also 
have evolved from something. Evolution has no ancestor to propose, but the 
evidence exactly fits the creation model, for creation insists that each 
animal type was created fully formed, with no evolutionary transition.
The evidence for creation is so strong; it is illogical to believe anything 
else. Only a religious commitment to atheism, or a desire for the approval 
of those atheists, who call themselves scholars, could lead one down this 
path. The Bible says that those who deny creation are "without excuse" 
(Romans 1:20).

When you fit in the missing gaps that even the "experts" can't fathom, I'd 
ask for your buddy further up the comment tree for some help if I was you 
sonny

Using Words doesn't justify your maturity you idiot, calling someone a

top_comment.text:
Personally, I believe in God, but let me just pretend I believe in neither 
God nor science.
So..
An omnipotent being decides to create a world of light and life in the 
midst of a dark void, he begins with the environment, goes onto mankind and 
builds on from that, creating necessities for the life forms until they are 
able to sustain themselves and create a common belief among each other, 
eventually spawning people who don't believe in the origin story and 
forcing the world into sin which causes God to flood the world and start 
from scratch once more, leading to Christianity being the most popular 
belief, Catholicism the second, and Atheism the third.
Versus.
The world is created in a big explosion and micro-organisms are born and 
reproduce and evolve over millions of years and eventually create multiple 
forms of intelligent life that inherit the earth, forming different races, 
cultures, traditions, and religions in turn. Forming the world with people 
who have very different ideals and beliefs from one another, once again 
with the same believes standing at their respective places.
One is science and one is God.
Now, people lean on God and people lean on science, but the truth of the 
matter here is that we aren't that different. To believe that the world was 
created by a God versus believing life was born by a universal explosion, 
honestly, they both take a lot of faith to believe in. And that's the bond 
of humanity, we believe in something and we will stand by that belief with 
our lives if it's threatened and insulted. We are all the same in this way.﻿

comments.text:
+Franco Castro Also we couldn't prove whether the giant squid actually 
exists, until we actually recorded a live specimen.

Science is simple:
Make up something imaginary (it can also be absurd)

Do many tests on that "something"

If you found anything that completely debunks the story, then it is fake.

If you cannot find anything that contradicts the story, and it works into 
many different other theories or assumptions we know to be true, then it is 
a "viable hypothesis"

If it is something that cannot be proven false, but also doesn't carry any 
tangible proof of working or existing then it become pseudoscience. So 
anything like warp drive, time machines, big foot, and once the giant squid.

Theories and Hypothesis are not suppose to be known as "true facts", and 
people should understand that theories can always be disprove (even the 
most accepted ones) You wouldn't believe how many changes the actual metric 
measurement underwent. You also wouldn't believe how many times the 
standard theory of the evolution of humans underwent. Even big bang theory 
has opposers and who knows, maybe the big bang theory is a bunch of 
hogwash! We just have to wait.

Personally, I believe Unicorns can exist in the future, because we are 
proceeding so well in genetically engineering. Although that poor 
genetically mutated horse wont follow all the magical tales told, people 
would probably agree, "Dang... That looks like a Unicorn". :3

top_comment.text:
Why are there so many religious nutjobs in this comment section?
"Well YOU don't know the answers, so obviously science is wrong and God is 
the only explanation!"

Oh piss off. Religion asks why, Science figures out how. The whole point of 
Scientific theory (and no, theory isn't "I think..." it's the best, most 
educated answer we have so far that isn't 100% confirmed and is designed to 
be built upon) is to find out the answers, no matter how long the process. 
Science doesn't just leave it as is because a magic man said so in a book 
which wasn't even written by him - God doesn't have a pen. You know, we 
used to believe God had made the world flat, and it was held up by a bunch 
of pillars. We also used to believe that God had put the Earth at the 
centre of the universe, as we were the "focal point of creation." Science 
(Galileo to be precise) discovered otherwise and Galileo released a book 
about his discovery. Wonder what the Church's response was? He was forced, 
as a 70 year old man, to get on his knees, kiss the popes ring and renounce 
his work as the writings of a madman.

You know, God is becoming the God of the gaps nowadays. Now that Evolution 
has gathered enough evidence to be considered a fact, Christians are now 
saying that God created the wiring needed for Evolution to take place, 
instead of God creating life as it was and it's always been perfect. Now 
that the Big Bang Theory has been all but proven, as it's impossible, 
Christians are saying that God set all the chemicals in place to make it 
happen, instead of the whole seven day bullshit.

Change is slowly happening, only time will tell how long it will take for 
religion to die out.﻿

A man sees a boy with a box of kittens.
The man goes over and says, "Ohhhh, what cute kittens you have!"
The boy replies proudly, "Thank you!  They are Christian kittens."
About a week later the man sees the boy again with the same batch of 
kittens. Once again he walks over and says, "My, those kittens are just so 
adorable!"
The boy proudly replies, "Thank you!  They are atheist kittens."
The man hesitates, and confused asks, "Wait a minute, weren't they 
Christian kittens before?"
The boy looks at the man and says, "Oh yes, but now they have their eyes

comments.text:
Oh I can't resist.  Here's another...

A righteous man was approached by God. God said "I'm going to send a flood 
in three days. Noah's building an ark and he doesn't have room for you, but 
you are a good man and I will save you."

The rain started and the man waited for God to save him. As the rain 
reached the man's knees, a boat came by. "Get in the boat, you're going to 
drown!" yelled the boatmen. "Nope. God said He would save me. I'll just 
wait," said the righteous man.

The rain reached the man's waist, and a second boat came by. "Get in, 
you're going to drown!" said the boatmen. "I won't drown," said the 
righteous man. "God said He would save me."

The rain reached the man's neck and a third boat came by. "You're going to 
drown!! Get in!!" cried the boatmen. "I'm fine! God said I would be saved. 
I trust Him!" said the righteous man.

The water closed over the man's head and he drowned. He found himself 
standing before God at the pearly gates.

"God, You said You would save me! I trusted You, and I drowned!" said the 
righteous man.

And God said, "I sent THREE boats, you dumbass!"
comments.author: Smiles2U4Ever

comments.text:
A Jew, a Catholic, and a Buddhist all die and go to heaven. They wait at 
the Pearly Gates for their turn with St. Peter.

The Jewish man steps up first. St. Peter checks the book, and then tells 
him, "You'll be in Room 21--but be quiet passing Room 7." Then he admits 
him.

The Catholic woman steps up second. St. Peter checks the book and then 
tells her, "You'll be in Room 14--but be quiet passing Room 7."  He then 
admits her.

The Buddhist man steps up. St. Peter checks the book and then tells him, 
"You'll be in Room 8--but be quiet passing Room 7."

The Buddhist starts in, but turns back to ask a question. "St. Peter, why 
must we be quiet passing Room 7?"

St. Peter smiles and replies, "That's the Baptists' room.  They like to 
think they're the only ones here."
comments.author: Smiles2U4Ever

comments.text:
+RoadToBasics
There is sufficient evidence to show the universe behaves in accordance to 
the multiverse theory. The fact that the "other universe" exist mostly as a 
mathematical structure, rather than a measurable one, doesn't change the 
way they influence the rest of the math, and thereby movement in our own 
universe.

To explain this more plainly. Imagine you find half an apple. It's 
reasonable to assume that it had a second half. Even if said second half 
fell into a black hole, and no longer exists, we know that an apple "makes 
sense" as a whole, and therefore a half-apple "makes sense" as having had 
another half attached to it.

Our universe has sufficient evidence to show it is like a "half apple". We 
can see there's a "missing half", but we cannot confirm, in any way, that 
said "missing half" actually exists.
comments.author: Saar Korren

comments.author: RoadToBasics

comments.text:
There are multiple universes, but they all have the same rules of physics, 
not different ones. They simply have a different superposition of matter 
and energy within them. Also, the greater majority of them are causally 
separate from our universe, meaning no information can be transferred 
between the different universes in any way. In that sense, they can be said 
to "not exist", since they cannot be measured, but they must exist for 
physics, as we know it, to make sense mathematically.

Well, just to toss my own opinion in this jumble of fun, nearly all science 
teachers I have come across have told me that science is never 100% proven. 
But we, as human beings, strive for the truth in the way everything works. 
That is where theories and hypotheses come from-our curiosities, questions, 
and discoveries. Sir Issac Newton was someone who came up with a 
hypothesis, tested it out probably thousands of times, and came to a 
conclusion that made sense for a long time(remember, this was back in the 
1600's). Proving a theory wrong in science is commonplace. And there are 
times where it isn't proven wrong, just...improved from what it was. But, 
with Religion-from my experiences-everything is absolute. It happened this 
way. This way is right, that way is wrong. If it isn't like this, then

certain entity. Religious texts are created by man. Who is to say that it

What you posted isn't evidence against anything; it's just assumptions 
based on your mental image of what the Christian God is. If you read over 
the Old Testament (that one testament your religion teacher probably 
awkwardly kept hidden away lest he scare the children), you'll find several 
reasons to believe that the god Christians believe in isn't exactly going 
to take care of us like babies. He's depicted as a very frightening power 
with a justice system very different to ours' more so than a tender, loving 
God who would give us a cuddle every day if he could. Just because when we 
love each other we don't smite them doesn't mean an almighty superpower 
isn't going to do so despite his love for you. It's like getting smacked on 
the butt by your parents when you do something wrong, but with 10000% more 
death and -100% less chance to learn from your mistakes. :P

Now I'm not saying religion is fact, just that your argument sounds 99% 
sourced from the New Testament and based purely on "If God is so nice, why 
did this bad stuff happen?" more so than fact.

As a side-note, your science book probably goes over a lot of scientific 
*theories*. Please don't believe these as fact. They are *theories*. At the 
drop of a hat they may be disproven and replaced with a new theory, whether 
that new one be mostly similar or largely different.

top_comment.text:
Maintain a population under 500 million is not a bad thing, and it doesn't 
mean 'kill everyone to reduce the population'.
There are other ways to reduce the global population, with the right 
education and a better quality of life. There's nothing sinister in such an 
idea, it's better for us humans, and it's better for the planet that we 
stop reproducing like crazy.
The less people reproduce, the better our quality of life will become, and 
the better our quality of life will be, the less we will reproduce, and 
this cycle will continue until we reach the desired number of people on the 
planet. 

Right now this is exactly what's happening in first world countries, but 
the problem is, is that the rest of the world is still poor, and it 
reproduces like crazy because their quality of life got a bit better, 
enough for the mortality rates to drop, but not enough for them to get out 
of their own cycle of lack of education, poverty and high birth rates. 
fortunately, there are people who are trying to solve this problem, and not 
by harming anyone. believe me, if this plan was sinister, no one would've 
tried to help those third world countries, they would've simply left them 
to their own fate, and watched their population reduced the way it did in 
the middle ages.﻿
top_comment.author: Blenderdick Snickersbar

comments.text:
+XxmusicXxplz Yeah well, I'm an  agnostic atheist.
Your idea is a bit too much though, as it goes against our basic human 
rights and freedom. The best way to solve the problem of over population, 
and child abuse and poverty, is by better education, social services, free 
and easy access to family planning clinics, that will provide counseling, 
education, free and easy access to birth control, and free woman's health 
clinics that will provide easy and free access to first trimester 
abortions. also, there's a need for mandatory special parenting training 
courses, and massive educational programs starting at an early age, that 
will educate kids on the seriousness and responsibility of having a child 
and being responsible of another human's life, and to educate them of the 
importance of becoming a grown, stable person who will be capable to 
support a family both financially and emotionally, before having a child. 
I know it sounds a bit too much, but believe me, it's better than to have 
all those children who are being born into incompetent and abusive families 
or extreme poverty, and unwanted children who will suffer from abuse from 
their parents simply for being born, and all of that, so that the world has 
more people competing for the same amount of resources, and causing more 
poverty and subsequent ignorance.

top_comment.text:
Had anyone heard of the Roanoke Island mystery? Basically, England sent 
some people to settle in North America. They found an island and called it 
Roanoke Island. One winter, the settlers were low on supplies, so they sent 
a ship to come back with supplies. When the ship came back, they found 
they're settlement ruined. All the people, gone. Houses, abandoned, and no 
sign of a fight. They found nothing that could explain the mysterious 
disappearance. The only thing they found was a message carved in a tree 
that read, 'Croatoan'. (I think thats what it said, it could be something 
else.) So, the settlers either left for a nearby island called Croatoan 
Island sure to the lack of supplies, our they were attacked by a native 
tribe called the Croatoans. ﻿
top_comment.author: Adri Elizabeth

comments.text: Very true indeed
comments.author: Bridget Kraft

comments.text:

Give this proof that Jesus was resurrected. Gimme sources. I think 
MisterProzilla nailed it, perhaps wording it better than I could have. 
Kudos to ye, Mr. Prozilla. You can have evidence pointing towards 
something, but without solid proof for it it's still a theory at the end of 
the day. Religion is the same, mostly without the positive evidence thing 
though. If negative evidence is found for any well-accepted scientific 
theory or for any large religion then, well, the aforementioned 'lots of 
money and respect' thing Prozilla mentioned will be the prize. You'll 
definitely hear about it. :P

+EcopiuM Like I said to "Our Saviour", give this proof. Cite sources. Where 
is science disproving anything regarding a larger power existing? I'm not 
seeing it, and such a discovery would be considered century-defining 
news. You call "Our Saviour" out for not citing sources, yet you fail to do 
the same. We have a term for that; hypocrite. Go look it up.

I think people get the wroooong idea when they think science and religion 
are inherently separate entities with colliding interests. They both serve 
to nurture our need for knowledge to overcome our fear of the unknown. I'm 
sure scientists wouldn't be angry and feel defeated if they somehow proved 
the existence of a god (not saying they will or won't). I think they'd be 
more than happy to have a new puzzle piece to solve more mysteries with 
instead, and such a large discovery would also net those there for the cash 
lots of green paper to spend.
comments.author: VenoMantis

comments.text:
Firstly, where is the proof of Jesus' resurrection? Solid sources, please. 
Secondly, you're correct in saying that the Big Bang has not been proven, 
nor can it be (I would encourage you to research the fundamental principles 
of the scientific method); however, it's the most likely scenario based on 
the evidence. It has been 'second opinioned' a great deal, if you're 
referring to peer review, as I think you are. The fact that's it's accepted 
as the working model of the genesis of the universe speaks to that. Like 
any good theory, it specifies conditions for its falsifiability (a 
steady-state universe, for example); if any scientist supplied 
incontrovertible proof that it is false, they would win the Nobel 
prize (and lots of money and respect) without a doubt. Lots of scientists 
are trying to do just that; they haven't managed yet, but that doesn't mean 
that they won't in the future. And that would be great, because we'd be one 
more step along the road to knowledge.
Thirdly, you cannot 'disprove' God for precisely the same reason you CAN 
theoretically disprove the Big Bang - claims of God's existence offer no 
conditions for their falsifiability. God's claimed existence is an 
unfounded assertion, which can be used to explain everything without 
recourse to any evidence; I can use the same trick with any fictitious 
character I care to imagine, and you'd be hard-pressed to refute my 
assertions. I can offer you an example, if you don't mind playing along 
with a small thought experiment?
comments.author: MisterProzilla

comments.text:
+RubikRem I am very sorry to read about the death of your friend, and I 
can't imagine how it must have hurt you. When I was in high school, another 
student who was younger than me committed suicide, and even though I didn't 
know him personally, my best friend was close to him and I know he probably 
wondered why nothing happened to prevent him from taking his own life. 
Similarly, I have wondered why people who I have known have died from 
illnesses (like cancer), in spite of how strong they were. 

I don't believe that your friend deserved to die the way he did, and I 
don't believe that the people who were killed by Hitler deserved to die in 
the Holocaust either. However, I do believe that some things that happen 
are simply out of our hands. I believe that everything will work out in the 
end, but that this current life is filled with challenges. The Bible 
acknowledges that we are presented with challenges to overcome. That book 
also tells us the way that God gave every human being the free will to make 
his or her own choices. You chose to care about your friend's well-being, 
and you are now choosing to remember him. Every person from Hitler to 
Martin Luther King Jr. has been able to make his or her own decisions. 
Every action that we take has results, too. I believe that God will judge 
all of us based on our actions. Until then, we can learn something from 
every event that happens in our lives, even if some events are difficult to 
handle. Even when bad things happen, the good things that come along can 
help to comfort us and strengthen us. That's how I believe God helps us, if 
we just ask him for help. 

Anyway,  I just wanted to let you know that I have been in your position 
before. Stay strong.
comments.author: BlueParadoxical

top_comment.text:
The "God" topic...

It is striking to me, about just how ignorant the majority of people are 
about religion, God, Christianity, the bible, and other religions... 
(though, it probably shouldn't be so unexpected as I was equally ignorant 
at one time).  Most of the arguments presented by believers in this forum 
are easily dismissed. 

I can, with great confidence, say that most believers (especially those 
posting here) simply accept what their parents and other authority figures 
have told them without ever having investigated the claims for themselves.  
As I was a self-claimed Christian for 28 years of my life, I did the same 
thing.  And the majority of those who claim to have investigated, have 
really only read the scriptures of their beliefs for evidence that the 
scripture is true instead of investigating the history of the religion.  
Using the bible as evidence that the bible is true is a fallacy called 
circular reasoning.  It's no different than saying the Egyptian god, Ra, is 
real because it's written on the walls of their buildings.  I would bet 
that most people don't understand that Thor and Odin are not just Marvel 
comic book characters, but they were worshiped and praised just as Jesus 
and YHWY (Christian god) are today.  This applies to all literature which 
we identify as mythology.  (Mythology = religion which is no longer 
practiced)

That said... there is no evidence that a god exists, nor is there any 
reason to think that one does.  Any claim to "evidence" supporting god, or 
reference to any natural occurrence suggesting to support the "god" claim 
is simply a demonstration of that particular individual's level of 
ignorance in regards to science and how our universe actually works.  The 
only arguments "for god" which have any chance of being true are held in 
three specific areas of science for which we do not yet have a sufficient 
explanation; Beginning of the Universe (notice I did NOT say "creation", 
there is no evidence to suggest it was deliberately "created"); The 
Beginning of Life (same.. ); and the emergence of consciousness 
(specifically the concept of "self", not just neuron input and response). 

These "places" in which we do not have a sufficient natural explanation are 
known as "gaps", and when god is used as the explanation it's known as a 
"god of the gaps".  While many theologists, such as William Lane Craig, 
will claim there is no such thing as a "god of the gaps", it is quite clear 
that that this the only kind of god which has ever existed.  We used to 
have many gaps during the days when Thor, Zeus, and Poseidon were worshiped 
in order to explain things like, thunder, lightning and tidal waves.  Now 
that we understand the nature of our environment, we no longer need gods to 
explain those natural phenomena.  Thus, as history shows, the "evidence" 
for the existence of god diminishes at a rate identical to that at which 
our scientific understanding of our natural world increases.

The most concise and logical explanation that there is no reason to believe 
a god exists is as follows:  All things that have ever been proven, have 
100% of the time been demonstrated to be the product of natural processes.  
This leaves no reason to suspect that any further discoveries will ever be 
demonstrated to be anything but the product of natural processes.﻿
top_comment.author: RedJama X

comments.text:
+RedJama X I would say that my home life and upbringing may lean more 
towards secular. We never really did talk about religion in the house, but 
my mom did take me to Sunday school until I was about 5 or 6 years old, and 
I did go to church off and on as a kid with some friends. That being said; 
I never believed in any sort of religion. One of my earliest memories is of 
me actually sitting in church and feeling uncomfortable upon figuring out 
that people thought the bible contained real stories. I honestly held the 
bible in the same light as the children's fables that try to teach you 
lessons on how to be a better person, and that church was just a communal 
gathering. 
After that I never really thought of religion or why I didn't believe it. I 
just knew I didn't and some people did (but I never talked about my 
feelings because I was scared to). I still went to church off and on, but 
just kept my mouth shut.
I was very much ignorant/oblivious when it came to religion. Hell, I didn't 
even know that the title of atheist existed until I was 14. haha

Now, as to not ramble, I started looking for reasons for my atheism around 
16 years old; starting off by watching Youtube atheist videos, watching 
science documentaries, and things of that nature.  While I held my beliefs 
firmly before then, that new found information just concreted everything 
for me. 
Around the same time though, out of general interest, I started studying 
the occult. I always found it interesting and fun to read about. As for 
what I wanted to believe during my time of weakness; it was still very much 
atheism in a way. It was just a way for me to try to escape my problems, 
and in turn I searched for fulfillment in trying to force myself to believe 
in something that I only had interest in as a subject study.  After going 
through all these play on words and mental gymnastics, I still knew that I 
didn't truly believe in anything of that manner, and then noticed why I 
tried in the first place. 
Just for reference, that little stint lasted a few months. I never tried to 
join in groups/orders, did any sort of ritual or prayer, or anything like 
that. It was very much just a mental thing to try to hide from my problems. 
Sorry for writing so much, but I wanted to be very clear.
comments.author: Orloks Might

comments.text:
I'm going to be *that* person for a moment. It wasn't solved. It will never 
officially be "solved" as it happened quite some time ago. They can 
theorize but the Jack the Ripper case will never be officially closed. They 
can't prove 100% that Aaron Kosminski committed the crimes. They can 
*theorize* that he did...but they've theorized others have. Due to the lack 
of hard evidence (due to the time periods data collection) it will be 
impossible to make a fully convincing argument.

You even said in your second sentence--"think." This means they didn't 
solve it. They *think* they know who did it. But they cannot be sure--and 
never will be. There are other cases that may never be solved while others 
still have a chance. For instance...Ramsey. The young girl found dead in 
her home. It is recent enough that someone can still admit to it or new 
information can come to light--as people are still living from when it 
happened. Jack the Ripper, however...well...everyone is dead. They only 
have old records and ill collected evidence.

Due to aforementioned statements...they won't ever be able to prove 
anything so the case can never officially be closed.

people after car accidents or a poor turn in health, and to get us to the 
moon; while other people will believe in the Bible, which is nothing more 
than a book. I don't believe in the Bible, but some morals I can support. 
Jesus said "Love thy neighbor", and anybody who says "Those who don't 
believe in the Bible are retarded!" or "Those who don't believe in science 
are retarded!" is not following that lesson. You are not following Jesus's 
lesson, so don't you dare call yourself a devout 
Catholic/Christian/whichever you choose to describe yourself as.
I am a different case all together. I won't sit here and say "Religion is 
bullshit!", nor will I sit here and say "Science is bullshit!" I can't 
argue against your claim, because you clearly have made up your mind on 
what you believe. As long as people stand on one end of the spectrum, both 
scientists and religious nuts will be at each other's throats. However, 
please hear me out.
Science has gotten things accomplished. Science has made discoveries in 
medicine, science has created the Internet, science has created so many 
things to save - and end - lives. However, science can't prove everything. 
Scientifically speaking, the bumble bee should not be able to fly. And yet 
it does. Some people have come back from the grave. However, things that 
have been told after death are scary. Some people come back and say "I saw 
God!", but some children are able to solve mysteries on how their past life 
was murdered because they had been reincarnated, or so the claim goes, and 
the pieces come together.
What has religion taught us? Not much. It hasn't developed the Internet or 
any break-through technologies, but here's the catch: I believe in 
miracles. Some peoples' faith is actually what they claim brings them 
through a tough time. There have been cases of people who should by all 
means have died but somehow they cling to their last threads of life and 
wake up on the operating table. Then there's the bumble bee.
Now here's what ties religion and science: nobody knows how the universe 
was created. All of it is just theory. Because nobody was there when the 
first star came to be, there is no one to say what happened. And I know 
that some people are going to say, "Oh if anything that proves God is 
real!" but it doesn't. Could God exist? Nothing says yes, but at the same 
time, nothing says no. Are there multiple gods? There's no proof one way or 
the other. Is the after life just some kind of mash-up of every speculation 
in existence? Maybe, maybe not. No one will know until they die, but once 
they die, that is it. There is no coming back. Once you die, and once 
you've been dead, you're gone. Then you know what happens.
I feel like religion and science could do some amazing things if they'd set 
it all aside and get into some kind of mindset. We don't have to love each 
other, but we shouldn't hate each other. Scientists will agree that hating 
someone for no reason is dumb, and any Catholic or Christian who is as 
devout as they claim should know that Jesus said "Love thy neighbor." It 
may not happen, but because religion can't be proven one way or the other, 
and science is still hazy. I feel like people should be taught as soon as 
possible to keep an open mind and to think for themselves, instead of 
immediately letting a book or test tubes think for them. Let's face it, the 
Bible isn't perfect; it says that a rapist is entitled to buy their victim 
as a slave, and there was once an error in a printing where it said "Thou 
shall commit adultery" instead of "Thou shall not commit adultery". And 
hey, science isn't perfect either. Heck, tapeworm eggs were sold as a 
miracle dieting pill before people realized it was killing them. The issue 
here is the fact that both religious nuts and science nuts tend to jump on 
the bandwagon too soon. I feel like we should delve into both with open 
arms, slowly and steadily at first, taking baby steps and learning to love 
each other before we hate. Then perhaps, by some God-sent yet scientific 
miracle, we can all get along a little better.

captions.text:
• From hieroglyphs indecipherable even today
to stories of hikers found dead in unexplainable

positions, we count 15 mysteries that have
yet to been solved or even understood

15 - Voynich Manuscript,
• A book created in the early 1400s that

is almost entirely composed of a language
never before seen and never deciphered since

• It comes with an array of colourful drawings
of strange plant-like creatures and celestial

diagrams, but the contents remain elusive
with some theorising it might've been a book

on early medieval medicine
• However, due to the amount of star charts,

some propose the book to have alien origins,
whereas others believe it was a hoax which

seems unlikely since the money and complexity
required would've been unbelievably high

• You can find the pages floating around
on the internet, but so far nobody has had

much luck
14 - Green Children,

• A pair of brother and sister that appeared
in the UK around the 12th century, in which

they turned up in a small village with completely
green skin, speaking an indecipherable language

and refusing to eat anything but bean pods
• After a while they learned English and

their skin lost its green tinge, claiming
they'd followed a river of light, heard the

sound of bells and then woke up outside the
town of Woolpit

• Theories claim the children to be of the
fabled Hollow Earth, a parallel dimension

or extraterrestrial abduction
13 - Rongorongo,

• An island off the southeastern Pacific
Ocean housing the Rapa Nui people who lived

over a 1,000 miles with no influence from
outside society

• They carved a number of these large Moai
head sculptures, but they also left behind

a series of wooden glyph tablets with an indecipherable
language - because of their isolation, it

is known to be one of the only independently
formed written languages ever witnessed

• The Easter Island mysteries are numerous,
and these are just a couple of examples

12 - Dyatlov Pass,
• This is a Russian story from a mountain

known to the locals as "dead mountain", in
which 10 people attempted to scale it using

a dangerous route
• They'd taken a wrong turn and wound up

lost, and when a search team went out to look
for them all that turned up were broken tents

filled with supplies, campers cutting THROUGH
their tent from the inside and bolting into

the night
• The search came across a few bodies, for

some reason only dressed in underwear and
socks, one even attempting to climb a tree

• The rest were found in a ditch, dressed
in the dead mens clothes, fractured skulls

and one with a missing tongue
• Nobody could ever explain what happened

here
11 - The Immortal Count,

• A man that kept showing up in history,
known to consort with some of Europe's most

famous figures like Casanova, Voltaire, King
Lous XV and George Washington

• Some say he was born in the early 1700s,
always turning up to set up an alchemy laboratory

- he speaks 12 languages, can play the violin,
paint, great wealth, never eating in public

and usually sold recipes to remove wrinkles
or dye hair

• He's been seen even up to the 21st century,
always associated with secret societies like

the Freemasons and Illuminati
• It's certainly possible mankind might've

discovered the key to immortality, and even
likely they'd keep the secret to themselves

simply not to incite chaos
10 - Beale Ciphers,

• A series of three ciphertexts that are
rumoured to reveal the location of the biggest

cache of treasures ever recorded in U.S history
- thousands of pounds of gold and jewels

• To this day only one of the ciphers was
cracked with the U.S declaration of independence

turning out to be the key, but it only revealed
the county where the treasure lay - that of

Bedford County in Virginia
• Today, treasure hunters dig through the

various hillsides, though it is considered
illegal to do so

9 - Phaistos Disc,
• A famous puzzle in the field of archaeology,

this disc was discovered in 1908 in the Minoan
palace of Phaistos

• It's made of a type of fired clay printed
with mysterious symbols and hieroglyphics,

believed to have been created around second
millennium BC

• Even though scholars came close to deciphering
it, they believe it to be written in a form

of ancient Crete called Linear A, but the
problem is they haven't even decoded Linear

A
8 - Pollock Twins,

• A story from 1957 about supposed reincarnation,
two girl sisters 11 and 6 years old killed

in a car accident in England, with their mother
giving birth to twins the following year

• One of the twins bore the exact same birth
marks as her deceased sister in exactly the

same places, and it got spookier when the
girls requested exactly the dead sisters'

toys which they couldn't possibly have known
about

• They also asked to be taken to places
they'd never heard of, like a park the departed

sisters had been too
7 - Alcatraz Prisoners,

• 1963, the Alcatraz Federal Penitentiary
off San Francisco - guards checked into the

cells of 3 inmates Clarence, John and Frank
and everything seemed fine

• Soon afterwards though, the guards realised
it wasn't men who were in the beds, but 3

dummies constructed from soap and toilet paper
• The trio never turned up again - their

bodies weren't discovered, nobody knows if
they made it to the mainland and escaped,

it's a huge mystery
6 - Lost City of Atlantis,

• The fabled island city, a world power
in the 10th millennium that vanished overnight

• Plato mentioned it in his story, that
it attacked Athens, failed and then was sunk

very soon after - but he claims it stood in
front of the Pillars of Hercules, and we haven't

found much evidence of this supposed city
in Earth's geography

• Two places could've been Atlantis, namely
the island of Santorini sunk by a volcano

or Sicily, which at the time was very similar
to the supposed Atlantis

• But both of these places were nowhere
near the Pillars

5 - Shugborough Inscription,
• An 18th century Shepherd's Monument located

in Staffordshire, England, with a recreated
sculpture of a famous painting known as Arcadian

Shepherds
• However, this painting contains the bizarre

series of letters, DOUOSVAVVM, a code left
by the Knights Templar apparently unbreakable

which reveals the location of the Holy Grail
• Some of the world's greatest minds have

attempted to reveal the secret, but all failed
- including Dickens and Charles Darwin

4 - Wow! Signal,
• 1977, a strong narrowband radio signal

detected from outer space by Jerry R. Ehman
working on the Big Ear radio telescope of

Ohio
• For 72 seconds a signal was coming in,

and Jerry was so excited that he wrote the
words "wow!" on the sheet of paper which become

the subject of heated media attention
• If it did come from extraterrestrials

in the Sagittarius cluster, they'd need to
be highly advanced sending out a signal far

more powerful than anything Earth has come
up with

• In 2012, we send back 10,000 Twitter messages
in the direction the signal originated from

3 - Cicada 3301,
• A puzzle that started in 2012 and has

continued ever since, a scannable puzzle game
that draws on cryptography, mathematics, literature,

hidden messages, philosophy and a host of
other topics

• The clues have sprung up in Poland, Hawaii,
Spain, Australia and Korea with the goal to

find intelligent people with the hope of meeting
those that solve all the puzzles

• Many on the internet believe it's a recruitment
tool for the CIA or other top secret government

organisation, or possibly to recruit for a
global think tank

• The last clue came up in January, and
will continue in January 2015

2 - Georgia Guidestones,
• Referred to as a modern Stonehenge located

in Elbert County, Georgia, it's a series of
stones engraved in eight different languages

relaying 10 new commandments for an age of
reason

• This stone doesn't contain any encrypted
message, but the reason and origin for them

is the mystery - who built them, and for what
purpose?

• Some of the commandments are vague and
somewhat sinister, including the first which

advises a human population of 500 million
- leading some to feel it's permission to

cull humanity
• Conspiracy theorists believe it to be

a message from a Luciferian secret society,
a new world order

1 - Jack the Ripper
• The most famous serial killer ever, he

who stalked the streets of London and murdered
prostitutes in gruesome, horrible ways

• His image was built up in folklore, misinformation
and media attention to such a degree that

we may never know the full story, but we do
know he killed at least 5 women and was within

seconds of getting caught
• Letters were forwarded to the police,

in which Jack taunts them and goes on about
how he'll keep killing, but these are believed

to have been fakes
• Jack the Ripper was never caught

title: 15 Biggest Unsolved Mysteries in the World
